rate.author: Explores the possibility that in 1421, a Chinese ship circumnavigated the globe, almost a century before the Europeans did.  Some provable facts, some hopeful conclusions by the author, some likely bullshit.  But a good read.
rate.title: 1421: The Year China Discovered America

statements.comment:
Fascinating! Life in China way back... Emperors, eunucs, concubines, and more.. The first 4-5 chapters focused on that, which I found most interesting. The rest detailed the evidence of Chinese explorations vs the others, which was interesting, too. 
(Full disclosure: I half listened the the audio book as I was driving across the country, never read a word.)

rate.comment: admittedly a bit too dramatic for my taste, the full movie that is avialable in this link: https://rumble.com/v56qjoy-climate-change-hoax-scam-of-a-century-new-movie.html presents the science that back up the people who say that likely there is no climate emergency, in detail i didn't see before . featuring some very prominent scientists that were proffesors at prestigous universities like harvard mit and caltech including a nobel prize winner physicist. i should add that if you put the name of the movie in google you can get many critics of it and it may be also intresting to read some of those articles for a balanced view.

rate.comment:
I feel increasingly guilty as I make this for family gatherings, but it is truly a favorite, and I tell myself that it is after all, just once a year or so that I am serving this to people. (it cannot even remotely be called healthy). 
I don't use any of the banana flavored pudding in my version, and I accidentally bought and used a cheesecake pudding once, which was really good.

this is very intresting video indeed. from the period of the corona restrictions my confidence in doctors plumetted somewhat. i also think that money can sway medical decisions but i don't know to what extent. i would be openminded to hear this doctor lectures nowdays if i had a terrible back pain for sure.

statements.comment:
In the Nerd'ster sense, your comment is about my comment.
But I think that it's actually about the video.
The Nerd'ster is confusing here, and I'd open to suggestions regarding how to make it more intuitive and easier to use.
If you want to comment on the video, then click the thumb up to the left of the video.
Also, if you want to recommend the video, then also choose 'recommend' (also a thumb up right now) in the rate dialog.

For now, I'll look at the icon options to replace the thumb up for any feeback with something more appropriate.

Thank you as always!

rate.title: A Revolution in Thought? - Dr Iain McGilchrist

rate.comment: this video is about the function of the right and left hemisphere based on scientific evidence from brain injuries of people and other kinds of data. it connects it to the rising totalitarian regimes that are starting to pop up in the west and the distancing of the people from nature and the rise of machines. it was a new prespective to me so was very thought provoking.

statements.comment: Nicely done!
